Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.raw_text: Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.proposition: Massachusetts law imposes an implied warranty of habitability and an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment in every residential tenancy.
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.support_reasoning: This excerpt is from a concurrence/dissent that explicitly disagrees with the majority’s chosen doctrinal vehicle (an implied warranty of habitability broader than the code) and instead advocates a narrower implied agreement tied to statutory and code standards. While the justice accepts that some implied obligation regarding habitability should exist and that the landlord and tenant obligations are mutually interdependent, he expressly “dissent[s]” from the majority’s broader implied warranty formulation. The quoted text does not discuss, endorse, or clearly establish an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment in every residential tenancy. Thus, this portion of the opinion, taken alone, does not clearly support the proposition as stated.
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.relevant_excerpt:
“I agree with the majority of the court that, at least as to dwelling units, the time has come to reconsider the rule so long imbedded in our law of landlord and tenant that ‘[t]here is no implied agreement, apart from fraud, that the demised premises are or will continue to be fit for occupancy or safe and in good repair ... and there is no obligation on the landlord to make repairs.’ …

The point at which I dissent from the opinion of the court is where it attempts to accomplish the first step by resort to an implied warranty of the fitness of the rented dwelling unit instead of by the implication of an agreement that the unit will comply with the minimum standards required therefor by law.”

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Massachusetts law imposes an implied warranty of habitability and an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment in every residential tenancy.

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A.proposition: Massachusetts law imposes an implied warranty of habitability and an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment in every residential tenancy.

Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.raw_text: Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744, 747–48 (2005)
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.proposition: Plaintiff promptly notified Defendant of the mouse problem after first discovering the droppings, doing so within a reasonable time and in a manner reasonably calculated to inform Defendant, as required by Massachusetts law for notice of conditions.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss any mouse problem, droppings, or when such a condition was first discovered or reported. Its notice analysis concerns when the landlord received an unsigned July 21 letter (found to be September 4) and holds that the tenant did not give notice before falling into rent arrears, thus failing the statutory prerequisite for relief under G.L. c. 239, § 8A. The case therefore does not support a proposition that the plaintiff promptly notified the defendant of a mouse problem within a reasonable time and manner under Massachusetts notice law.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.relevant_excerpt: “Here, the trial judge found that York did not have notice of the complained of conditions until September 4, 2001, some two months into Casey’s rent arrearage and after she had received a notice to quit. We have found no reason in our review of the evidence to dispute this finding and conclude, therefore, that it was not clearly erroneous.”

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: The presence of rodents and rodent droppings in the Premises constitutes a material violation of the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., including but not limited to 105 C.M.R. 410.550 (pest control) and 105 C.M.R. 410.602 (conditions deemed to endanger or impair health or safety).

105 C.M.R. 410.550 (pest control).proposition: The presence of rodents and rodent droppings in the Premises constitutes a material violation of the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., including but not limited to 105 C.M.R. 410.550 (pest control) and 105 C.M.R. 410.602 (conditions deemed to endanger or impair health or safety).

105 C.M.R. 410.602 (conditions deemed to.raw_text: 105 C.M.R. 410.602 (conditions deemed to endanger or impair health or safety)
105 C.M.R. 410.602 (conditions deemed to.proposition: The presence of rodents and rodent droppings in the Premises constitutes a material violation of the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., including but not limited to 105 C.M.R. 410.550 (pest control) and 105 C.M.R. 410.602 (conditions deemed to endanger or impair health or safety).

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7\u00a7 127A\u2013127L.proposition: Under G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L and the State Sanitary Code, landlords are responsible for maintaining dwellings in compliance with minimum standards of fitness for human habitation, including the duty to exterminate rodents and other pests and to maintain the structure in rodent-free condition.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 717\.proposition: The continuing presence of rodents and rodent droppings constitutes a “serious interference” with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment of the Premises within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, § 14, and Massachusetts case law, including Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 717–19 (1977) (landlord liable where actions or omissions cause substantial interference with tenant’s quiet enjoyment) and Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 283–84 (1994).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 717\.support_reasoning: Blackett concerns bar noise from a neighboring commercial tenant and articulates the general rule that a landlord is liable for substantial interference with quiet enjoyment when the interference is the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted, and that the landlord’s conduct, not intent, is controlling. It does not address rodents, unsanitary conditions, or G.L. c. 186, § 14 specifically, nor does it define “serious interference” in that statutory context. Thus, Blackett provides analogical support for landlord liability for substantial interferences but does not directly support the specific proposition about rodents constituting a “serious interference” under § 14.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 717\.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Although some of our opinions have spoken of particular action or inaction by a landlord as showing a presumed intention to evict, the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.”

Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 283–84 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.proposition: The continuing presence of rodents and rodent droppings constitutes a “serious interference” with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment of the Premises within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, § 14, and Massachusetts case law, including Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 717–19 (1977) (landlord liable where actions or omissions cause substantial interference with tenant’s quiet enjoyment) and Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 283–84 (1994).
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.support_reasoning: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth. deals with drug-related criminal activity in common areas and whether the landlord’s omissions regarding security measures can constitute a serious interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. The opinion does not discuss rodents, vermin, or sanitary/pest conditions at all, nor does it state that the presence of rodents or rodent droppings is a serious interference. While Doe confirms that substantial interferences in common areas can breach quiet enjoyment, it cannot be cited as authority specifically for rodents constituting such an interference.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises. … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: To establish a claim under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a tenant must show a serious interference with her quiet enjoyment caused by the landlord or by someone acting for the landlord.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The court squarely interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14’s quiet enjoyment clause, explaining that it covers serious interferences with the tenant’s tenancy and that liability arises from the landlord’s own conduct that causes such interference. The opinion ties the statutory phrase "quiet enjoyment" to its common-law meaning (freedom from serious interferences that impair the character and value of the premises) and upholds liability where the landlord’s failure to maintain sanitary conditions allowed repeated flooding that interfered with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment. This directly supports the proposition that a tenant must show a serious interference with quiet enjoyment caused by the landlord or one acting for the landlord.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929) (quoting from Brande v. Grace, 154 Mass. 210, 212 [1891]). … Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is violated when conditions substantially impair the character and value of the leased premises and the landlord fails to take reasonable steps to remedy them after notice.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.support_reasoning: The court explains that liability under the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment requires at least negligent conduct and specifically notes that a landlord’s failure to repair known defects after notice is a common basis for § 14 liability. It states that to obtain relief for lead paint poisoning, the landlord must have notice or reason to know of the condition and fail to take appropriate corrective measures, which aligns with the proposition that a violation occurs when conditions substantially impair the premises and the landlord fails to take reasonable steps to remedy them after notice.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.relevant_excerpt: We noted that a landlord’s failure “to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.” ... Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord... Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.

Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass..raw_text: Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass. 708, 720–21 (2002)
Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass..proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is violated when conditions substantially impair the character and value of the leased premises and the landlord fails to take reasonable steps to remedy them after notice.
Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass..support_reasoning: The case concerns adoption of the Restatement (Second) of Property § 7.1’s mutually dependent covenants rule in commercial leases, not the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The court explicitly finds no constructive eviction and does not analyze or articulate a standard for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment in terms of substantial impairment plus failure to remedy after notice. Instead, it holds that, even without untenantability, a tenant may terminate when deprived of a significant inducement to the lease and the landlord fails to cure, which is a different doctrinal basis than quiet enjoyment.
Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The requirements of the rule we have adopted today are different from the requirements necessary to demonstrate a constructive eviction. For example, the rule does not require that the premises be ‘untenantable for the purposes for which they were used,’ in order for the tenant to terminate the lease and vacate the premises. It is sufficient for the tenant to demonstrate the landlord’s failure, after notice, to perform a promise that was a significant inducement to the tenant’s entering the lease in the first instance.”

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 200–02 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: Landlords have a non-delegable duty to maintain residential premises in compliance with the State Sanitary Code and to make necessary repairs and take steps to abate conditions that endanger or materially impair the health, safety, or well-being of tenants.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely grounds the landlord’s obligations in the State Sanitary Code and treats compliance as a non-waivable, strict obligation, independent of landlord fault. The court states that the landlord must at least comply with minimum State sanitary and building code standards, that these duties cannot be waived or bargained away, and that reasonable efforts or lack of fault do not excuse noncompliance; this effectively makes the duty to maintain habitable conditions under the Code non-delegable. The case also emphasizes the landlord’s duty to provide adequate heat and hot water and links breach of that duty to tenant remedies (rent abatement).
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “In the latter instance, the landlord must comply at least with minimum standards prescribed by the State building and sanitary codes. … The Code puts the landlord on notice that it must supply adequate heat and hot water. State Sanitary Code, Art. II, Regulations 5, 6 (1969) … Those duties cannot be waived, bargained away, or qualified by customary practice. … The landlord’s lack of fault and reasonable efforts to repair do not prolong the duty to pay full rent.”

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 185C, § 3, because this is a civil action arising out of a residential landlord–tenant relationship, including claims concerning quiet enjoyment and conditions of residential rental property.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 185C, § 3, because this is a civil action arising out of a residential landlord–tenant relationship, including claims concerning quiet enjoyment and conditions of residential rental property.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1\u20132.proposition: Venue is proper in the Worcester Division of the District Court Department / Central Division of the Housing Court because the Premises are located in Worcester, Massachusetts, and all relevant events occurred within this division.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7\u00a7 3\u20134.proposition: Venue is proper in the Worcester Division of the District Court Department / Central Division of the Housing Court because the Premises are located in Worcester, Massachusetts, and all relevant events occurred within this division.

G.L. c. 186.proposition: At all times relevant, Defendant has been the landlord of the Premises within the meaning of G.L. c. 186 and applicable Massachusetts common law.

Westland Housing Corp. v. Scott, 312 Mas.raw_text: Westland Housing Corp. v. Scott, 312 Mass. 375, 381–82 (1942)
Westland Housing Corp. v. Scott, 312 Mas.proposition: The presence of rodent droppings in the kitchen and food storage areas has effectively deprived Plaintiff of the full and safe use of that portion of the Premises, resulting in a partial constructive eviction of that area.
Westland Housing Corp. v. Scott, 312 Mas.support_reasoning: The case does support the general doctrine of constructive eviction where a landlord’s acts or omissions render premises unfit for use, but it does not involve or discuss rodent droppings, kitchens, or partial constructive eviction of a particular area of a unit. The constructive eviction found here was based on smoke, soot, fumes, and resulting health issues that deprived the tenant of use and enjoyment of the entire apartment. Using this case as authority specifically for rodent contamination of kitchen/food storage areas and partial constructive eviction overstates and mischaracterizes its holding.
Westland Housing Corp. v. Scott, 312 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “A constructive eviction has been defined… as ‘some act of a permanent character, done by the landlord with the intention and effect of depriving the tenant of the enjoyment of the demised premises or some part of it, to which he yields, abandoning the possession within a reasonable time.’ … In all the circumstances we are of opinion that the landlord must be presumed to have intended the natural consequences of its own acts… in failing to remedy the conditions which deprived the tenant of the use and enjoyment of the premises over a substantial period of time, and that the judge was warranted… in concluding that the tenant had been evicted by the landlord.”
